data.title: ‘Renounce Nuclear Ambitions,’ Trump Warns Iran While Nuclear Shares Turn Volatile
data.description:
Key points:
  • DJT was down 2.28% in after-hours trading, despite high discussion on Stocktwits.
  • The stock became highly discussed on Stocktwits, but it was still down 2.28% after hours, with neutral sentiment.
  • Nuclear stocks moved up and down, and traders had mixed views about how the tensions could affect the market.

Shares of Trump Media & Technology Group (DJT) fell on Friday after President Donald Trump gave a strong speech about Iran in which he said the regime must "never have a nuclear weapon" and warned that the U.S. would take more military action if Tehran didn't give up its nuclear goals.

Trump said in his speech that the US is carrying out a "massive and ongoing operation" to get rid of threats from Iran that are about to happen. He promised to destroy Iran's missile infrastructure and stop proxy forces from operating in the region. He said that Iran “rejected every opportunity to renounce their nuclear ambitions, and we can't take it anymore.”

He said that the campaign was important for U.S. national security and told Iran's security forces to put down their weapons, promising them immunity or "certain death."

After the speech, DJT's retail popularity rose, and it became the most talked-about stock on Stocktwits, as traders reacted to rising global tensions.

Trump Media & Technology Group (DJT) was down 2.28% in after-hours trading on Saturday. On Stocktwits, the retail sentiment around DJT remained in ‘neutral’ territory, with chatter at ‘high’ levels over the past day.

Nuclear Stocks Show Mixed Movement In After-hours

On the other hand, nuclear power-related stocks showed mixed after-hours price movements and volatility. Constellation Energy (CEG) ended the day with a 1.95% increase. After hours, it fell by 0.28%.

Vistra Corp (VST) closed down 1.66%, and then dropped to $173.40, down 0.28%, in extended trade. BWX Technologies (BWXT) ended the day at $205.98, down 0.61%. After hours, it was almost flat at $206.00.

Centrus Energy (LEU) fell 3.97% and then rose 0.15% after hours. Cameco (CCJ) rose a little to 0.19% and then rose 0.24% after the bell. NuScale Power (SMR) dropped 3.60% to $12.85 and stayed the same in after-hours trading. Oklo (OKLO), on the other hand, dropped 8.86% to $62.95 and then dropped a little more to $62.80, down 0.24%, in extended hours.

How Stocktwits Community Responded

Retail commentary showed that people had mixed feelings. Some traders said that long-term instability could help nuclear energy as part of a long-term energy security strategy.

https://www.stocktwits.com/redsstocktwits/message/646195210

https://www.stocktwits.com/AZ_09/message/646194942

Some people said that if the conflict gets worse, the risk to the whole market could outweigh any sector-specific tailwinds.

https://www.stocktwits.com/I_HODL_GOLD/message/646195221

As tensions between countries rise, traders seem more interested in whether the situation will escalate into a long-term military campaign and how defense, energy, and risk assets will react over the next few sessions.

data.title: How Greg Abel's First Letter to Berkshire Shareholders Is Different — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Andy Serwer

This morning for the first time in 60 years, Berkshire Hathaway shareholders are reading the company's annual stockholder letter — and it isn't written by Warren Buffett. Instead, the letter is authored by Berkshire's new CEO, 63-year-old Greg Abel.

This year's letter comes in at 18 pages, significantly longer than Buffett's letters, which tended to run 10-15 pages. In it, Abel lays out what he considers to be Berkshire's company culture and he walks shareholders through its operating businesses. The comprehensive nature of the report might reflect Abel's desire to show investors he is fully knowledgeable of Berkshire's ins and outs — and that he has a firm grip on his remit.

"I am actually pretty impressed," says Macrae Sykes, a longtime Berkshire watcher and portfolio manager at Gabelli Financial Services Opportunities ETF (GABF). "I give him a gold medal for laying out the technical aspects of the company. The letter is very comprehensive, his knowledge is incredible which is not a surprise, but still impressive to see."

For decades, Buffett, 95, wrote what became a much-anticipated and much-pored over communication, highly-valued both for its analysis of Berkshire, markets, and sometimes even humanity, as well as its folksy wisdom. Though Buffett remains company chairman, he stepped down as CEO on Jan. 1. In a November news release, Buffett noted that he "will no longer be writing Berkshire's annual report." (A February communication confirmed "the annual report will include Greg Abel's first annual letter to shareholders.") And so what was long "the chairman's letter" at Berkshire has been replaced, for the time being at least, by the CEO's letter.

Expectations have been high amongst Berkshire watchers over this year's letter, with two broad and obvious questions front and center: Exactly which company and business issues will Abel address in his first letter, and how is the tone, style, and even length of the letter different from Buffett's?

First question first. What did Abel focus on? He begins the letter not surprisingly with a tribute to Buffett, writing that Buffett "is arguably the greatest investor of all time, with generations benefiting from his investment acumen. He has also been a remarkable CEO... (To Warren's great frustration, this letter begins with these observations — yet we all know they are true.)"

In the company culture section, Abel cites a letter he sent to employees "emphasiz[ing] that Berkshire's culture and values remain unchanged and will continue into perpetuity."

Here, Abel also points to the company's decentralized model, its integrity, financial strength, and capital discipline. In the latter section, Abel says the company may make share repurchases — but would not be paying a dividend at this time, which some investors had anticipated.

Sykes notes, though, that Abel says this is subject to board review. "That leaves the door open," Sykes says. In the letter, Abel also speaks to the company's risk management, and name-checks that unit's top executive, Ajit Jain, 74. He makes no mention of Jain retiring, which some investors wondered about, but says Jain would be on stage with the CEO at the company's annual meeting in Omaha in May.

Next Abel speaks to Berkshire's performance, walking investors through the health of the company's operating business units. As for its investment portfolio, where investors might be seeking clarity as to who is directly overseeing it going forward, Abel writes that "equity investments are fundamental to our capital allocation activities; responsibility ultimately resides with me as CEO. Ted Weschler manages about 6% of our investments, including a portion of the portfolio formerly overseen by Todd Combs. Ted's impact extends beyond these investments, as he continues to play a broader role in assessing significant opportunities, providing valuable input on our businesses, and supporting Berkshire in various other ways."

As part of the letter, Abel also welcomes new CFO Chuck Chang, succeeding Marc Hamburg, and Mike O'Sullivan as Berkshire's first general counsel. The letter closes with Abel describing the upcoming annual meeting, stressing continuity with previous ones.

The letter's last line — "We move forward with great intent and purpose" — resonated with Sykes. "I love how he concluded," Sykes says. "It's a wonderful way to end the letter, and gives you lots of confidence."

There were items that Abel does not address. The letter does not speak directly to any plans he might have concerning Berkshire's massive cash trove of $373 billion as of 2025 year-end, more than any other American company's. Nor does he say will buy stock Berkshire stock for himself, as his ownership of company stock is tiny compared to Buffett's $150 billion stake in the company.

Stylistically, Abel's letter differs from Buffett's in ways one might expect. It contains fewer of the homilies or folksy tales for which Buffett was famous. (Not even any metaphors about ice hockey, a sport with which the Canadian-native Abel is enamored.) Nor are there any stories about Berkshire vice chairman Charlie Munger, who passed away in late 2023.

Another changed facet is that veteran business journalist, Carol Loomis, is no longer editing Berkshire's letter to shareholders, as she did for Buffett beginning in 1977. Loomis, 96, and Buffett, who still play bridge together online, would go back and forth for weeks as part of the editing process before the letter came out. Those days are no more, though, and as Buffett no longer writes the letter, Loomis no longer edits it.

The Berkshire letter to shareholders is Greg Abel's baby now.

Write to Andy Serwer at andy.serwer@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.
